For me personally, this is by far the best survival game ever. I also think this game teaches pretty good management skills, whether this is intentional or not. And I would like to spend time describing this below because the game is awesome and is worth playing.

You may be able to survive on your own for some time, but you will suffer to beat the bosses without proper armor and weapons. Unlocking the armor and weapons takes a significant amount of time and will be super boring without the village, so you build one. First, you are running around doing things, setting up logistics, building buildings, etc. But then you realize: you can't do everything by yourself, surprise!!! It's unavailable, unsustainable, repetitive  and boring.

So you learn how to delegate more and more stuff, how to set up processes and how to eventually remove yourself from the equation so you have time to explore. And this is hard because something is going wrong all the time: constant attacks from wolves, occasional bloon moons, bear attacks, smolkers chew through your precious storage stuff...  I had to start over and over to figure optimal way to build the village. And finally ali got it! Fun and relief!

And then the first winter... Everyone froze to death or died from hunger. Start over. Focused on clothes. Doing great, survived the first winter, yay! The second year expanding and exploring.

The second winter. Invasion. I had warriors trained, but stone weapons. Everyone got wiped out. Start over. Now I am at the point my second invasion is coming and I have a little army, but my mine is dead so I will have to setup logistics to bring iron from far away. If I survive the invasion of course.

And this constant learning and planning ahead is what makes this game great. I definitely recommend it.

I write reviews infrequently, so a game must be truly compelling for me to dedicate time to writing one. Aska is such a game.

As a fan of survival-crafting games and, to a lesser extent, city builders, I began Aska with few preconceptions. To call it a pleasant surprise is a profound understatement. This review will delineate what Aska is, what it is not, what I found exceptional, and what elements may not appeal to all players.

Executive Summary:

Who will enjoy Aska: Players who thrive on challenge, production and village management, and learning intricate crafting chains (which include unique mini-games).

Who may dislike Aska: Those seeking deep, complex combat (it is engaging but mechanically simple), players who dislike intricate NPC/supply chain management, or those who prefer fast-paced, combat-centric gameplay.

In-Depth Analysis:

Aska begins like a typical survival title: gathering berries, crafting basic tools, and finding shelter. However, the game quickly transitions as you establish roots and build a base. This phase introduces the core mechanic of managing NPCs you summon for your tribe, requiring thoughtful village planning. These summoned villagers are not mere helpers; they are fundamental to your progression.

Regarding the villagers: while they generally don't match a player's efficiency, they are highly competent at specific tasks and significantly reduce the player's workload. A key part of the game's learning curve involves mastering their job assignments, work-marker placement, and perk specializations. Critically, this system serves as an elegant solution to tedium; any task you find monotonous can be automated by assigning it to a villager.

As your settlement expands with more buildings and villagers, Aska evolves into a full-fledged production management game. While managing five villagers is simple, scaling to twenty‚Äîall requiring food, clothing, and housing‚Äîmakes mastering production chains an absolute necessity.

This leads to your first winter, a formidable challenge that serves as a harsh audit of your planning. Many players will spend it learning from their mistakes, huddling by a fire as their village starves and freezes. While this steep difficulty might not appeal to everyone (though guides are available), I found it refreshing. The genuine threat of winter, and the realization that a restart with "lessons learned" was the best path forward, was a high point.

From this point, the game loop solidifies: maintain village and production equilibrium, gear up your tribe, and hunt bosses while exploring your starting island. Concurrently, you will likely work towards building a ship, stocking it with goods and warriors to raid the outside world.

Aska is a game of intricate systems. After the standard crafting introduction (gather, click), the game layers on complexity. Advanced items require multi-step production chains, and key professions like ironworking and carpentry introduce bespoke mini-games. Again, if these prove tedious, they can be fully delegated to villagers. Even base location, terrain management, and defensive walling are iterative learning processes.

This iterative nature makes starting a "new run" feel not like a chore, but an exciting opportunity to optimize: to build more efficiently, test new locations, and experiment with different village layouts.

Aska is, for me, one of the most memorable gaming experiences in recent memory. I had initially shelved the game to avoid burnout before its full release, but one specific update pulled me back in.

The Game Changer: The Sea Raiding Update

I returned to Aska specifically for the Sea Raiding update, and it is transformative. A primary drawback of the earlier game was a finite map and a lack of clear endgame goals. While the starting island is large enough to occupy you for the first couple of winters, it is ultimately finite. The Sea Raiding update shatters this limitation. It allows you to build a Karvi (ship) and launch expeditions with eight of your villagers.

Having only scratched the surface of this feature, I can confirm it is a masterstroke. Aska was already a fantastic game for its first few in-game years, but this update fundamentally alters the experience. The world is now massively expanded (its full size is, as yet, unknown to me), offering raids for resources that may be dwindling on your home island. The sailing mechanics‚Äîwhich include a learning curve for those unfamiliar with basic sailing concepts‚Äîfeel authentic and immersive. As a sailor myself, I appreciate the subtle touches. This update elevates Aska into an elite class of survival-crafting titles.

Conclusion

Is Aska for everyone? Certainly not. But if its core pillars‚Äîchallenge, management, and deep systems‚Äîresonate with you, you may lose hundreds of hours exploring its subtle complexities. If, however, you seek a traditional, action-heavy survival game or a "fire and forget" experience, you will likely find Aska's deliberate pace and intricate management tedious.

[h3][b]It Does Get Better[/b][/h3]

This is the first thing I'd say when considering to buy. My first 8 hours as a new player was miserable, frusterating, and tedious. There's a learning curve with how things work and what to build first, but once you figure it out it does turn into a rather solid survival-city management game. I'm currently on my second play through and enjoying it just as much as the first (after I figured out what to do.) As a side bar, if you want to know the biggest tip I could give for a new player is... rush the farm, start growing flaks every season, make clothes. Winter is coming. And it'll make you want to quit if you and your village isn't fully clothed.

[h3]Not Without Its Problems - Bugs and Changes Needed[/h3]

I'm going to begin by listing bugs and suggested changes, and I'll list them based on how severe they are to the overall flow of the game.

-Villagers assigned to the Blacksmith plain do not want to work. Sometimes, I can get a few nails out of them, but they mostly are too concerned with filling their storage with random crap, then complaining its full, OR they spend all their time constantly lighting the fire in the Metalwork, even if they're not assigned to tasks there. This is really bad for late game, requiring the player to fully take over all the metal needs, which is a lot late.

-Woodcutters prioritize cutting trees rather than carrying the logs back to their storages. Which leads to the next problem.

-There needs to be a "Supplier" role that functions the same way Builder does, in that it can be infinite and they will fill stations and warehouse storages. Currently, you can have a limited amount of villagers per warehouse storing what they have storages for. However, every crafting station spends half their time going to the warehouse, rather than crafting. And you need an excessive amount of warehouses and workers to keep the supply moving. This needs streamlined, badly. You can have a million of the materials they need laying around but just not enough hands to load the warehouse before the worker needs more.

-Market workers hate their job, and will completely break often just standing there doing nothing. This is also where the "Supplier" job would make things significantly better since the Market/Outpost system is a broken mess right now, and it doesn't fix the problems of constantly being on short supply of logs and other needed goods.

-Villagers should be able to use carts outside of market workers. They're terribly inefficient due to it.

-Bosses are, horrendous. They're stupidly easy. To the point where you could be naked with a wooden hammer and smoke them. Alternatively, the Draugr boss and the stone Jotun Giant, like to spam knock down moves repeatedly, which means you stand up, then get locked in a long stand up animation, over and over... and over.

-Iron Plates do not drop from gear when they break. I love the tool system how they drop their metal part, however - this is a huge problem later since mines are not infinite and will eventually run out of iron, as Plates are expensive. They need to drop when broken.

-Carpenters are terrible at their job. Although I do believe this is fully from the issue of supply not being able to ever fully catch up with demand. Again, "Supplier" role. Not a house, but an alternative role like how the builder works. We need an infinite amount.

-Walls need a bigger leeway when it comes to counting as connecting. I've had them literally kissing and it still says red. Takes too much playing around to get it to decide it's good.

-Blood Moons and especially Invasions are WAY too easy. A complete joke easy. I know the game received criticism for being too hard early in its life... I'd like to try how that was with the current fixes because there is way too little of a threat, and I have zero army in my village. I can solo it without problem. Invasions are supposed to be this huge build up, but it's like a bunch of gnomes with knives come out instead. I think the best way to do this is to add more options when creating the worlds. More enemies on Blood Moons and Invasions to make them a real threat would go a long way for replayability. If you see a review saying, "ITS SO HARD" or "YOU WILL RESTART IN THIS GAME", they're full of it. It's a joke fighting wise.

-Cheiftan's house should function the same way the longhouse does, with being able to expand it. Can hardly fit anything in my house.

-Aska's, the female character, neck is... really long? lol.

-Animal models look horrifyingly awful, specifically the dogs. Need a model update.

-Combat could use some updating but this is quite minor. Even if it went live with the current combat it'd still be fine, just could be better.

-When doing carpentry or blacksmithing, allow us to keep swinging while being able to rotate, gets annoying having the animation stop.

-Dodge rolling needs some forward momentum.

Overall I would recommend the game right now as once I figured enough out to survive winter and work around the kinks I'm still very much enjoying myself. The learning curve is a slight hill, not a mountain, so if you're interested give it a shot and just remember--this is really important--it does get better.

First thing - the elephant in the room that many reviews seem to be discussing: Valheim.

Many other reviews seem to fall into two categories: those that compare everything in the game to Valheim (tend to be negative reviews) - and those that stress that this game IS NOT VALHEIM - nor is it intended to be a Valheim clone. Just as It would be silly to compare the original NES Ninja Gaiden to AC: Shadows (both are set in "ninja worlds" and both are nominally action games), you should not go in expecting Aska to be a clone of Valheim just because both are set in mythic Viking worlds and are crafting/survival games.

Now that that's out of the way - this game is not for everyone. In my experience so far, it is much more Rimworld/Dwarf Fortress than it is AC: Valhalla. There is much more focus on city building, survival, crafting, and managing your villagers than it is hack-and-slash combat. So if you're looking to jump in and have an axe covered in Jotun blood within the first few hours, you'll be very disappointed. 

Now that we've now what kind of game it is - how does it stack up? 
I had this game on my wishlist for a very long time before actually picking it up and trying it out - I'd seen a lot of "mixed reviews" that kept me from leaping in, but most of what I'd seen showed a lot of promise and seemed like something I might actually love. - I'm glad I picked it up when I did. 

The game is still in early access. As I mentioned before, I kind of followed Aska's progress for a while before I bought it, and one thing I noticed during that period that made me pull the trigger: The Devs seem very dedicated to fulfilling the ambitions they have set for themselves with this game. It seems like just about every time I look at the store page of this game, steam is always showing a LIVE stream of the devs playing their game (not a re-stream like so many others).

The BAD:

1. Learning Curve
There is a steep learning curve to village/villager management, especially if you're not familiar with colony management sims. But once you get the hang of it, the game opens up pretty quickly. I recommend watching a youtube video or two if you are not accustom to colony sim mechanics - it will save you lots of time. There is sort of a tutorial, but it needs a lot of work. However, the tooltips are GREAT (once you know where to look) - things went easier once I realized most of the information I wanted to know was THERE, I just needed to know where to look for it. 
2. Random Map Generator
The random map generation needs a bit of work. IMO, they should make it so at least 1 cave is somewhat close to the starting area. 
3. UI
The interface/default keybind system takes some getting used to, it's probably not what most people are used to in similar genres, and could use some work. Some of the UI stuff is innovative and I actually grew to like better than other games so count this partially in the "good" section of the review- e.g. hold 'R' to harvest automatically pulls out the correct tool from your inventory and starts harvesting the rock/log/etc in front of you as opposed to having to select the correct tool yourself and then start chopping - this saves a lot of the typical headaches of swapping tools and moving them on/off your hotbar. However, the menu navigation still needs some work though and feels clunky sometimes.
4. Terraforming 
So far they've done a pretty good job on this one - but it's still not perfect, and those imperfections can lead to big headaches - like that one little pyramid spike of dirt that you can seem to get rid of, or the hump on the edge of the ramp that your character only seems to be able to walk over without falling down a level 50% of the time. 
Also dedicated hotkeys for level terrain/create path/build road would go a long way here - this ties in to some of my UI complaints.
5. Custom Difficulty settings
Some more options would be nice here - from what I understand these are a fairly recent addition, but there are some settings I'm still not seeing a "just right" option for. The settings for monster attack frequency/day length/season length, etc. could use more options in between what's currently offered.

The Good: 
1. Bugs (or lack thereof)
There are very few bugs that I've encountered - I think I've had 1 crash to desktop? 
New features are constantly being added. Patches seem to be frequent and substantive - rebalancing things, responding to community feedback, fixing QOL things, etc. Even the multiplayer seems relatively smooth compared to loads of other similar games that seem to struggle with multiplayer in EA. Aska has FAR FEWER BUGS than I remember in Valheim (which still had optimization issues last time I played it).
2. Breadth, scope, multiplayer, everything else?
There is SO much in this game to keep you busy/having fun I don't know where to begin. And I would have said that before they added viking ships raids in the most recent patch. Hours often fly by when I'm playing this game and before I know it, I've barely even left the immediate area of the village and the season is changing again. From my limited experience with multiplayer, I get the feeling that the chains of micromanagement aren't as big of a deal (if that's really not your thing), however the villagers are there to do most of that grunt work to begin with, so maybe I just enjoy the grind too much. Also you can tame wolf cubs, fish, poop, farm, fight alien things in caves, defend against raids, ATTACK monster camps, built outposts to help with logistics, cook, go raiding on your viking ship, fortify your village, oh yeah and there's a whole magic system too, which I've barely had a chance to touch it because I've been too engaged just building my village.

3. Price
If this type of game seems like something you would like, it's well worth the money even at early access, this game is a great buy.

The Hope:
I really hope the devs stick to realizing their ambitions and don't release 1.0 too early. The game still needs work on several QOL things, however, none of the issues are game-ruining and it's incredibly enjoyable as-is. There is also some progression and content that I don't think is in the game yet, so if you're someone who wants to "beat the game" you might want to hold off until 1.0 - but I'm excited for what comes next. I don't know what their plan is for mod support on this game, but as some other reviewers have already said, mods could play a HUGE role in this game's future (in a good way). 

TL;DR:
Current meta rating of "mostly positive" feels unfair - I'd say it should be "very positive" with a potential to go higher at full release --especially at this price point. it's a Fantastic game if you like Rimworld but want it a little bit more hands-on. There are so many different game mechanics in Aska, I feel that it has something for just about everyone. Co-op multiplayer is great, but single player is viable. Very few bugs encountered, but QOL needs some polish still. I will continue to look forward to what they add next, which hopefully will eventually include mod support.

This is a pretty phenomenal game.  Definitely under appreciated, in my opinion.

It's essentially a survival colony builder.  You spend your time crafting but also hiring villagers, defending your village, going out into the world to find cool things, and automating your production at home.  The seasons play a big role and you have to manage how you approach the year.

The crafting early game is very laborious, but I found it fun still... it takes a while to complete any building because of the array of resources needed, but it also feels good when you finish something.  I like the way buildings can be expanded out, and I also really love that every little part of the manufacturing process has its own in game management.  For example you see leather on the racks drying and tanning, and you craft your thread at the loom but your clothes at the workbench, stuff like that.

The combat is decent.  It's not souls-level, but I would put it on par with other games of this style like Medieval Dynasty or even something like Enshrouded.

The world is beautiful and well designed, and I really like the quality of life features like using the Z key to scan for resources in your local vicinity.

There's so much about this game that it's hard to pin point any single thing to call out here, but I can say for certain that this game has me hooked much harder than most games of its style and I really look forward to building out a much larger village and going out on raids at some point.

Definitely recommended.

Some reality checks for you though since it can be hard to get that from the pictures and videos.

- This is not an adventure game, it's a survival village sim with adventurous elements, think of Banished but rather than you being this "God" from top down, you are literally inside it as one of the characters.
- The main focus is village, villagers, creating a nice cozy place that can be defended from threats. 
- People will be mauled by bears and wolves.
- People will freeze to death
- Building isn't instant, it takes time, so any new project has to come with forethought, e.g. Don't  build an armorsmith if your villagers don't have basic clothing
- If you love attention to detail, or paying attention to detail, then this game is great. If not, then this game is not for you, there is a great deal of micromanagement and you need to learn how to "Move with intent"
- You will restart the game often, so learn to play before investing into a server with your friends. (Or watch some guides)
- The dedicated server menu sucks shit, which I hope they will improve. If you rent a server, there is no search function so you need to find it manually from a list. Then after that first connection, it will be added as a favorite for easy connection and will show up at the top. 
- Do some research on good seeds before starting a serious playthrough, there are many that suck out there.
- Combat is more dark-soulsy than Valheim or other hack and slash games of this type. 
- Invasions are cruel and don't care about your new warehouse, so plan ahead when placing critical objects.

Constant resupply runs kill momentum. Procedural gen means no reliable paths. Pure luck if you stumble on the endgame content.
It's Early Access, so patience is key. Devs are active with hotfixes. If you've got endless time and love a grind, it'll reward you. Otherwise, play something else.

I want to love this game so badly.  I've given it a VERY fair chance of 40h+ of gameplay, but the game is simply too rough and it just leaves me frustrated.  The problems fall into a few categories, and these problems intertwine to create an unsatisfying, clunky, and time-wasting experience.

-Terrible UI
Starting with this problem because it amplifies the other problems.  The UI is somehow both claustrophobic and barebones at the same time in a twisted, clunky mess.  Basic colony sim mechanics like setting schedules, restricting access to resources, setting collection areas, and creating bills at a workshop are a time-consuming chore in ASKA, especially as you scale up past the beginning of the game.  The map and many menus become overwhelming (and sometimes practically useless) very quickly because they're too cluttered and poorly set up.

-Bad colonist system
In ASKA, you assign people to a job and they'll only do that.  A farmer will farm and do nothing else.  If there's nothing to farm, they stand around.  You can wrestle with the frustrating menus to micromanage the villagers, but that quickly becomes impossible because buildings have worker limits.  A woodcutting house (the top tier) can only allow three people to work.  This means you're going to set a villager to a task and leave them, effectively setting your automation cap.  The result is that ASKA isn't really a colony sim; it's part automation sim, part survival builder, balanced like a colony sim, and it's the worst of all three.  

Like a colony sim, things are expensive and time consuming.  In any other colony sim like RimWorld or Oxygen Not Included, you can assign colonists to priority tasks, but everyone can do almost everything when needed (for example, you can have a crew of builders, but if there's nothing to build, they can help farm or mine).   In ASKA, one woodcutter house means three woodcutters max.   

Like an automation sim, you'll try to scale up.  "Just make more woodcutter houses!"  But... it's balanced like a colony sim.  Three more woodcutters means another VERY expensive woodcutting house, three more expensive beds in an expensive shelter, three more daily meals, three more sets of clothes to regularly make, and three more sets of bloodstones (the resource to summon villagers).  Imagine playing Satisfactory or Factorio, but it takes an hour of gameplay for your automated resource gatherers to get what you need to make... another resource gatherer.  

Like a survival builder, you'll do a lot of the labor yourself.  Since clothes, tools, an even buildings degrade over time and require upkeep, it's hard to establish stockpiles through automation alone.  If wood is your bottleneck, you'll need to go grind the wood yourself, even with an established village of 50+ people.  Imagine playing The Forest or Valheim, but everything is three times as expensive to make and instead of clicking a button to make a new clothes with the stuff you've farmed, you need to wait for villagers to process the materials or slowly process them yourself.   

-The villagers are simply too stupid.  
Workers will stand at a station and do nothing, and often not even give you an error message explaining their problem.  Hauling mechanics are terrible; the mine will be overflowing with iron, but the smelter will run out there and grab a small handful of iron instead of filling their inventory.  You're supposed to solve this with warehouses, markets, and outposts, but those mechanics are terrible too.  The warehouse will pull logs from the carpenter and the carpenter will pull them right back.  Setting restrictions is frustrating and unintuitive.  Many important in-game systems aren't explained.  Getting villagers to help in combat or even defend themselves is a massive chore.  

-Not enough content, too much grinding.
This is a cynical take, but I believe the devs have made the game artificially time-consuming to stretch out the play time and justify this early access price.  If you could have half the village help cut wood or if buildings and items needed less grinding to make, you'd get through 90% the content in a day or two of playing.  

Once you're processing hardwood and smelting iron, that's pretty much it.  A lot of really expensive buildings and items do close to nothing.  Three people can get to the end game content in a few hours, and then spend 20 hours upgrading buildings to get tiny boosts to productivity.  Sailing and raiding let you get the same basic resources that are plentiful on the mainland.

For some, progression is being artistic and collecting resources to make a beautiful settlement with cool buildings and an interesting layout.  It's very disappointing in ASKA.  Buildings all look the same and all look very "early game," even at the top tier.  Stone pathways, thatch buildings, rocks, and mud.  The "beautify" or "comfort" furniture barely changes the look of anything.  Many boulders can't be removed or covered, and need to annoyingly worked around.

Atmosphere ‚Äì Honestly, it‚Äôs meh.

The game tries to present a mystical, moody world, but it never sticks. The one cool moment ‚Äî the giant skeleton titan walking into the ocean ‚Äî is the high point. After that, the world feels flat.

Lighting makes it worse:

* Nights are barely darker than daytime.
* Torches are so bright they‚Äôre pointless.
* You check your villagers and realise it‚Äôs ‚Äúmidnight,‚Äù even though it looks like early evening.

The world never feels dangerous or atmospheric, just washed-out and foggy.

Progression ‚Äì Slow, messy, frustrating.

Progression depends heavily on NPC villagers‚Ä¶ and they behave like malfunctioning preschoolers.

They complain constantly (‚Äúdon‚Äôt like this food,‚Äù ‚Äúlost this item,‚Äù ‚Äúdon‚Äôt know what to do‚Äù), they freeze, they wander, they ignore tasks, and half the time you‚Äôre not progressing ‚Äî you‚Äôre babysitting.

It doesn‚Äôt feel like building a settlement.
It feels like managing a daycare for confused NPCs.

Early Game ‚Äì Fine for a few hours, then becomes a slog

Gather ‚Üí craft ‚Üí build works until hour 5 or 6.
Then reality hits:

* Everything slows down.
* NPCs break constantly.
* You redo tasks they should handle.
* Progression crawls.

The survival fantasy collapses into repetitive labour.

THE ‚ÄúMEDIOCRE‚Äù (WHICH ISN‚ÄôT EVEN MEDIOCRE)

The first island is tiny

You can sprint around the entire starting island in under an hour. Exploration dies immediately.

Enemy areas look like slapped-together placeholders

Graveyards aren‚Äôt eerie.
Corrupted zones aren‚Äôt threatening.
Wight camps look like afterthoughts.
Draugr areas feel like stretched, dumbed-down Valheim rejects.

There‚Äôs no atmosphere, no creativity, no tension. Just flat, empty design.

THE BAD (WHERE THE GAME COMPLETELY FALLS APART)

1. Combat Is Straight-Up Awful

Combat is the weakest system in the entire game.

* Fighting is mindless button-spam.
* Rolling is unreliable; you still get hit.
* Shield blocking barely works; you take huge damage anyway.
* Heavy attacks have long windups and weak results.
* Hitboxes are inconsistent.
* Nothing feels weighty, responsive, or satisfying.

It‚Äôs not skill-based combat ‚Äî it‚Äôs flailing.

2. Ranged Combat Is Miserable

Using a bow is torture.

* Arrows drop like bricks.
* Damage is pathetic.
* Accuracy is unreliable.
* Hunting a rabbit can take 10‚Äì20 arrows.

Ranged combat feels like a broken mini-game.

3. Villager AI Is a Catastrophic Mess

Every system depending on villagers collapses because villagers simply‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt work.

* They forget tasks.
* They freeze.
* They wander in circles.
* They complain constantly.
* They refuse to forage/carry/build without perfect conditions.

You aren‚Äôt building a settlement ‚Äî you‚Äôre dragging it uphill yourself.

4. Visual Readability Is Terrible

Everything blends into the environment:

* Plants
* Animals
* Herbs
* Enemies
* Resource nodes

So the game gives you a highlight button (Z)‚Ä¶ and then puts a **cooldown** on it.
The one tool that makes visibility bearable is limited.

Highlight ‚Üí cooldown ‚Üí blindness ‚Üí squinting ‚Üí suffering.

Terrible design.

5. The Grind Becomes Exhausting

Midgame becomes relentless:

* Too much manual gathering
* Too many repetitive chores
* Too many NPC failures
* Too much walking back and forth

The game stops being survival and becomes unpaid manual labour.

6. Enemies Are Bland and Forgettable

Wights look like zombies.
Skeletons are skeletons.
Draugr are tall, dumbed-down Valheim rejects.

They all behave the same.
Nothing is memorable.
Nothing is unique.
Nothing is interesting.

7. The Bear Is Completely Broken

The giant bear is visually fine, but mechanically absurd:

* Massive knockback
* 30+ HP per hit
* Targets you instantly
* Villagers die fast
* Fighting it alone is suicide
* Fighting it with villagers is still suicide

It‚Äôs not a boss.
It‚Äôs a griefing mechanic.

Even the community says the bear is overtuned and unfair.

8. The Death System Is Outdated and Annoying

Every other survival game uses a corpse, gravestone, or bag so you can reclaim your gear in one click.

ASKA refuses to adopt this basic standard.

When you die:
Your entire inventory explodes onto the ground as individual items.

Tools, armour, mats, weapons, resources ‚Äî all dumped separately.

You must pick up each piece manually.
It‚Äôs slow, irritating, and unnecessary.
It adds nothing to the game except frustration.

This system feels a decade outdated.

FINAL VERDICT

ASKA has ambition, but ambition isn‚Äôt enough.
Broken combat, broken AI, bland enemies, bad readability, poor progression, and tedious systems drag the entire game down.

I refunded it once.
I bought it again hoping it improved.
It disappointed me both times.

Final Score: 4.5/10 ‚Äì Not recommended in its current state.

Aska the Micromanaging game. 40 some odd hours in and I can't stand to play it anymore. I love these types of games and I liked Aska before I had 30 or so villagers. Early game is fun and learning how to play Aska is fun but Late game is a huge chore.

Playing Aska reminded me of one of those early 2000s MMOs where you'd hop on into this epic bounding open world full of details and new possibilities, but then on actually playing it you start to realize all of the pitfalls in that vision and how little you can actually do for the most part, and that your character keeps glitching and phasing in and out through the terrain. 

To address the mammoth in the room, Aska borrows much from Valheim, some improvements are made yet somehow they traded these in for qualities which should have been kept from it. The graphics in Aska are nicer than Vheim, but you'll quickly come to see that everything looks very similar and there's nothing that really makes it stand out. A casual glance of a gameplay from Enshrouded or Conan Exiles would easily be confused with this. Valheim at least is instantly (infamously) recognizablewith it's dated graphics and unique design. 

The user interface is also bad, being hard to navigate and the tutorial does little to actually guide you on how to use it or how to progress through the game. Again comparing something like Minecraft, Rust, Green Hell, or Valheim, in these games they're designed to be easily understood and picked up. Punch tree/ pick up rock then punch tree until wooden blocks come out, then build a house. In Aska, because the focus is on fancy graphics I couldn't see where the resources I'd mined / harvested were half the time as everything blended into the hummus of the ground and I had to keep tapping 'z' to highlight where the items had dropped. 
Food and resource management was annoying as you have to figure out that you're supposed to find little water bowls occurring in nature to drink water from. Lots of things exist, but they never really tell you how it all fits together unless you've read all of the crafting pages. There's a unique resource called 'Jotun Blood' but you won't know what it does unless you happen to hover over the exact recipe which happens to mention it. There's a lot of assumed knowledge in this. 

Crafting is annoying as you have to memorize what the recipes are as you can't just drop ingredients onto a table to craft or pin recipes (in Stranded Deep if you pinned a shelter recipe the list would stay on the right side of your HUD until complete). I had to keep bringing up the menu in order to see what I was making. Building is annoying as you lose the level of customisation that other settlement builders like Fallout 4 or Raft had where you can't even build your own structures. At least in Valheim or ARK you can place a smithy inside of a walled structure you made. Why can't I make a giant castle or even a simple walled hut like what we had in Fallout? The only sense of enclosure and 'base building' you can really see is the outer enclosure of the city walls / fences. Eventually, once you've levelled all the ground around your base, and paved enough roads, it'll be done, but it'll look the same as everyone else's. It's definitely no No Man's Sky where you can build your own base or home and add your own touch to it. 

Combat is rather bland and the threats aren't really anything amazing. There's no giant troll or ice dragon moments like you got from Valheim. The bears and giant wolves were cool, but they're rare, can come out of nowhere and completely decimate your enclosure. You'll be expected to either learn from this or just die again. Once you've got a little army of warriors to lead with though the game starts to lose all urgency or danger and the enemies become a breeze to get by. There's nothing to do late game other than build some more.

It comes off as a rough cut chunk that really needs much more polish and structure design form the bottom up to get a player engaged. Cool concept, but doesn't look like it will ever be finished properly.

My advice with this game is to wait.  It may look pretty okay, but it's poorly programmed and I don't mean optimized.  I'm actually surprised it runs as well as it does on my sub-par cheap computer.  I can have 75 villagers with only it shuddering when it auto-saves or I blow up something (20 dupes on Oxygen Not Included and I can only use the slowest speed in the game).

As for the programming, I'll use the bloomery as a simple example.  You have input: coal and iron ore and then output: iron bloom.  You have to blacklist every villager who could possibly use coal and iron ore and your warehouse workers from taking these items out of the input.  They'll even take it out of the furnace while you're using it.  Same with a cookhouse, villagers will take the raw food out of the cook pot WHILE ITS COOKING.  So there's a lot of micromanaging not the game, but the poor programming.  The bloomery workers will not go put the finished product into the warehouse, they'll chase you around complaining that output is full.  And I do mean chase, they'll also stand in front of you interfering with whatever you're doing if you're in their range.  You'll have to update the whitelist for every building every time you get a new villager.  You can't set the whitelist by job, it's by individual person and individual building.  So if you have 75 villagers, you'll do this 75 times for probably 25% of your buildings if not more.  Fun.  They also won't pick up more than what they need for one task (or even one item for one task), so most of their time is spent going back and forth.

As for ranges, they don't work properly either.  I don't know what the range of individual buildings are because they're not indicated.  Warehouses do have a limited range where their workers will pick things up, but that's in no way suggested or anything you can see.  There are woodcutting markers, foraging, building, hunting, stonecutting, and forestry with tiny ranges.  And the villagers assigned to those jobs will not go to some of them if they're too far away, but will keep asking for more markers.  What their range is, who knows.  You'll end up with 30 markers for foragers dotting your map and still not enough.  It's ridiculous.  It's not like Flotsam where you can resize them and assign a different number of villagers or specify what they're gathering.  Nope, you'll end up with dozens (if not over a hundred) of little markers all over the map, have the foragers complain about not having enough markers, then realize they're not going out to the markers you placed.  Hunters will leave dead animals, meat, hide, all over the map and never go back and get them.  Same with woodcutters.

The durability is a joke.  If there weren't a mod to change this, this alone would render the game unplayable for me.  Every tool you make can break in a day.  **ALL** of your tools can break in a day because of the ridiculous durability.  I've played plenty of games with durability and I think this is by far the worst.  Same with the food spoilage--now we've all bought some raspberries from the store and could swear they stared molding on the drive home, but this game said "hold my beer".  Same with clothes.  Also, once you make better clothes for your villagers, there's no way to break down the old clothes so they're every where.  Absolutely everywhere.  And they didn't make folded clothes, so the pants and shirts just stand up like there's someone wearing them, which is also ridiculous.  

Mines are the second joke.  They're the only source of iron ore and there are about 2-4 mines on the map.  They run out and the solution the devs came up with is that you can bomb the corridors of the mine to cause a collapse.  But this doesn't renew the mines, it just brings back a wall which has maybe 45 ore in it.  You need about 4-5 to make anything (even nails) so this isn't a lot.  It also means you have to rebomb the mine in about 8 different places every single day.  You can't have a villager do this and you also won't have enough resources to do this.  I would say this is a way to force having outposts at those other mines, but judging from the rest of the game, this isn't the case, it's just poorly balanced.  

This poor balance is most obvious with the woodcutters.  They'll wipe out whatever space you mark for them, cutting down tree after tree and leave bark, sticks, resin, and logs everywhere because all they need is the one long-stick that comes from a 100 ft tree.  

There's also not a whole lot to do.  The world has some monsters: wolves, skeletons, wights, and bears in their own POIs and periodic invasions, but other than needing flax and the jotun blood to summon new villagers, exploration of the island is just bland.  You're only coming across the same resources: food, flax, and sticks.  There's no lore, there's no reward, there's nothing that stands out.  I don't know what the endgame is supposed to be, but even with the new harbor update the question is why?  There's no progression.  You "level up" individual skills like gathering, stonecutting, etc., but there's no difference from one level to the next.  If there wasn't a little  message saying that you did level up, you'd never be able to tell.

You can't create quivers for arrows, sheathe for your swords, a bigger backpack, or anything of the like.  If you want to be involved in the building of your town, which there's not much else to do, you'll need a hoe, pickaxe, axe, roadbuilder, your weapons (sword, shield, bow and arrows), knife and they all take up space in your pack so you have about 8-12 spaces left for sticks, thatch, leather, or whatever.  This doesn't change the entire game.

You can eventually make slightly better armor and weapons, but either the tooltips are wrong or the early "crude heater shield" does more damage than the "reinforced" version.  Same with the later weapons, the pickaxes can do the same amount of damage according to the tooltips, so on paper (so to speak) there's no benefit to making the later items.

There's so much for them to fix and with these problems existing from the beginning as far as I can tell from reading comments all over the internet, I doubt they'll ever get to it all to make it a well-rounded game.  It's a jumbled mess right now with awkward UI.  Quick example, they made a sound option for eating and drinking, but if you mute that slider, you still get the eating and drinking effects....  There's also options to extend the day hours and seasons, but they in no way compensated for resources or respawns.  Some respawns are triggered by the beginning of a season.

All in all, I bought it after watching three or four people play this on youtube and you could glean some of this from watching them, but wouldn't get the full picture of the brokeness.  So for people hoping inexplicably for a solid early access game, pass for now.

This is a tough one. I want to make clear that this game not getting a recommend doesnt mean that it's totally shit, I just wouldnt recommend it to a standard audience. Its just way too dang fiddly. It feels like something like Medieval Dynasty with some giant caveats which ill try to go in to.

So first of all, we're dealing with one of those "Realistic" build system for a survival game. That means you're usually carrying 1 log at a time. Backwards and forwards. For hours of your life. Thats okay. That can be fine. We've seen it on Medieval Dynasty, Green Hell and others. The problem with ASKA is that this very rarely rewards the player themself. Youre doing this in service of making a workstation for an NPC, and they are exactly that. The time goes so fast they dont have time to have a life and by the time they walk to a gather point, recreation time is done. If we contrast this with Green Hell, you might spend 15 minutes solid setting up a mud area, but once you do, you can make mud structures, the gameplay loop circles on itself and it feels good to play. Youre not stamping out a mud hut that an NPC that youre going to have to micromanage until the end of time is going to use. You're making something that adds new gameplay mechanics and new building options.

With that point briefly touched on, I'll move on to the villagers. Its like herding minecraft villagers. Absolutely nothing is automatically assigned. If you dont tell them exactly where to go, what to do and where to eat, theyll stand there like a fish with a dumb look on their face, and then walk to the nearest food source to them at the time, the farm full of raw food instead of the kitchen. Their behaviors will change between save files (They wont shit in my current world, as I've tried to give this game plenty of chances. No fertilizer for you nerd). Their jobs arent matched up, so the charcoal burner will be sitting around all day waiting for the woodcutter to get bark, then sticks, then long sticks, then logs, then sap, then eventually the firewood he needs, at which point everyone froze to death. You can forbid NPCs from using storage but then whitelist others, but it doesnt make clear what this even does. What if I dont want the npcs eating the raw food from the farm? If I blacklist them all will the farmer stop storing food there? I dont know the game never tells me what the blacklist does. The tutorial assumes im functionally retarded and most of the audience arent going to have been raised on minecraft in 2025. The design is so disperate and strange.

The combat is Dark Souls for people who have had a brain anyuerism. There is really nothing else to say. It's slow, clunky and barely responds. You can dodge for iframes, block or parry, and all of your attacks have stupid animations an actual fighter would never do and take up as much stamina as running for 50m. Its the weakest part of th game but the developer insists on shoving it up your ass every second night. Its one of those games where the enemies arent there to kill you they're there to break all those buildings you spent hours taking logs to because good gameplay is wasting your fucking time. I have a job.

This is a small gripe but I dont understand why the building system had to be so realistic when you can make a magic potion that turns you into a bird, and you fight a stone golem and zombies. Ultra realistic gritty build system where you gather every log one by one doesnt marry up with magic giants very well unless you can eventually use your magic to make the giants work for you and carry 100 large stones at a time or something, and if youre doing that, you need to do it at the start. Make the dogs easier to tame, make them get their own food or even hunt food for/with you and make the whole game about conquering/taming this place to make life easier for the humans.

Honestly, talking about all the bad things in a row just frustrates me because there are hints of something good under there. Its like the beta for Valheim, a title I've been avoiding mentioning simply so I can reference it in this closing statement. ASKA just never picked it's lane. It wanted to be too many things. And ultimately, I can see the birth of the idea in my mind, and its a good one. "I really wish I had some NPCs to help me build in Valheim". Thats a mod I would download immediately for that lonely ass game. But if youre going to make something succinct you need to lean into the parts of your game that make it different and this game leaned far too hard into the elements that made it the same as other existing games that are VERY hard to compete with. You try making a realistic build system to rival the likes of green hell, where I know where every single stick in the structure is because I put it there, and you're going to have to work pretty hard. This game very frequently has its toes just over the line of patience where if structures had maybe a few less difficult items like large stone or a little more interactivity and ability to customize them, get new gameplay mechanics and new stuff for making them, it might be okay, but this game has a habit of feeling like a chore even to me, and I play Warframe... I'd like to try fishing if I weren't worried about keeping everyone alive.
